comments.body: Do we need to worry about people upgrading to 2.9 and breaking things?

@pabelanger  I don't believe so.

I think there are two scenarios we need to think about.

1. User specified no ansible_network_os. 
This will still trigger the auto-detection and the outcome will be the same, either the auto detection is successful and the correct network_os is used, or the auto-detection fails and default is uses
2. User specified ansible_network_os = default
Previously this would trigger the auto-detection (despite the user wanting to use the default network_os) which would fail and default would be used. After the change, the result will be the same, (but auto-detection will not have been tried).

I think the only scenario that could cause an issue is if someone was specifying ansible_network_os=default in order to trigger auto-detection (which I don't believe was documented anywhere)

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +118,122 @@If ``ansible_network_os`` is not specified for a host, then Ansible will attempt to automatically detect what ``network_os`` plugin to use.

``ansible_network_os`` auto-detection can also be triggered by using ``auto`` as the ``ansible_network_os``. (Note: Previously ``default`` was used instead of ``auto``).

.. include:: shared_snippets/SSH_warning.txt
